results.description:
NOTE:  Please tune into our Live Stream if the event is full and/or you're unable to physically attend. Register here: 

https://thisismetis.formstack.com/forms/data_science

______

Join us for an evening of storytelling and interactive discussion with DataKind! 


Around the world, individuals with diverse data science skills are working together with social change organizations to apply data science to some of the world’s toughest challenges. Who are these individuals? 

At this event, you'll meet four of them and hear stories of their cutting-edge work. See how you, too, can get involved in this growing Data for Good movement!

Format: Remarks and facilitated discussion with Q&A

Speakers & Bios:

Ana Areias, World Bank
Ana Areias uses data science for good at the World Bank. Currently, her projects include building poverty prediction models and using online job boards data to estimate real-time unemployment statistics in India.

Bob Filbin, Crisis Text Line
Bob Filbin is chief data scientist at Crisis Text Line, the first large-scale 24/7 national crisis line for teens -- on the medium they use and trust most: texting.


Cat Miller, Flatiron Health
After surviving MIT, Cat has spent most of her career working with technology in health care -- from trying to create early-response warnings for CHF patients to helping hospitals manage resources. Now at Flatiron Health, she works with large cancer data sets to find the meaningful patterns in real-world data.


Kush Varshney, IBM
Kush is a research staff member with the Data Science group at IBM Research and a data ambassador with DataKind.

Miriam Young, DataKind (moderator)
Miriam is the Communications Specialist at DataKind and has built her career supporting the pro bono movement, bringing business, technology, and social sector experts together to change the world.


Learning Objectives:

At the end of the session, participants will:

•  Understand what the “data revolution” and “Data for Good” movement are all about

•  Feel inspired by the potential of data science to address social challenges

• Gain awareness of key ethical considerations involved in these projects

• Understand how they, too, can join the “Data for Good” movement
results.name: Stories from the Frontlines of Data Science for Good

results.description:
This Meetup Mashup includes the following communities:

Axiologue: http://www.meetup.com/Axiologue/

Information Architecture: 

http://www.meetup.com/information_architecture/

Semiotics Web: http://www.meetup.com/SemioticsWeb/

Moderator: Chris Novell

Chris Novell has a B.Ed and MBA. She worked as an internal consultant at Chase Manhattan Bank and as an Oppenheimer Research Department assistant. She has also trained in the CERT program (Community Emergency Response Team).

She has developed some deep learning techniques and created some educational tools and likes to enable students to have what she describes as a "peak learning experience." She has observed that young children absorb more sound bites than most adults realize. Interaction Design concepts have inspired her to design interactive and participatory art. While digital solutions can be powerful, Chris notes that mechanical ones can be magical, too. She marvels at the learning opportunities that Meetup groups have created.


Speakers:

Nathaniel Davis

A New System. A New Architecture. A New Model.

Understanding, building and maintaining a digital ecosystem requires a broader meaning of the term “system architecture.” A system architecture must express more than the function of information technology (IT). It must include the architecture of our human engagement with technology and the context within which our human and technology interactions persist. As a result, a new reference model for system architecture is paramount.

In this talk, Nathaniel will discuss the organizational and collaborative challenges that business stakeholders, product managers, technologists, UI designers, usability engineers, user experience designers and information science professionals face to create and manage human-centered digital ecosystems. Nathaniel will propose a new model for digital experience architecture and call for digital professionals to advocate a new digital “system” that thrives on the coherent and thoughtful architecture of both design and infrastructure.

Nathaniel Davis is the author of the upcoming book “Information Architecture: Theory, Science and Practice” due in 2016. Nathaniel is a veteran of information architecture, web strategy and design. He advises on IA and UX strategy and is founder of the DSIA Research Initiative where he curates the DSIA Portal of Information Architecture - a public knowledge base of articles and resources based on his research. Nathaniel is the information architecture columnist for UXmatters and a contributing guest writer for the Bulletin of The Association for Information Science and Technology (ASIS&T). In addition to curating the DSIA Research Initiative, Nathaniel Davis serves as director of information architecture for a Fortune 100 company.

Noreen Whysel

IA Gateway

The Information Architecture Gateway is conceived as a portal that helps IA practitioners, libraries, associations, universities, researchers, and other groups and individuals from various sectors to connect to, search, find, and use tools. The IA Gateway is a collaborative, multidisciplinary model for bringing together users from different disciplines within IA to serve other ecosystems, such as learning, communications, security, accessibility, resilence and identity, and in turn, help them learn and discover IA in their own ecosystems.

Noreen Whysel is a founder of the IA Gateway. She is the Community Manager for the OWASP Foundation and serves on several other technical committees and organizations, including the board of GISMO, a NYC regional chapter of the NY State GIS Association and business liaison for NYGeoCATs, a planned geodata catalyst group. She is the UX Committee Vice Chair of the Identity Ecosystem Working Group and an advisor to the Brooklyn SBDC Technology Transfer Days program. Also, she served for many years as the Operations Manager of the Information Architecture Institute and has spoken frequently on topics in Information Architecture, emergency management, and linked open data. Noreen holds a BA in Psychology from Columbia University and a MSLIS from Pratt Institute.

Michel Biezunski

“Topic Maps: Then and Now”

Topic Maps is an international standard published in 2000 and aimed at providing information owners ways to organize their information according to their meaning. Since that time, technology has evolved, search technologies are now generalized practice. Topic Maps are still relevant, since they offer a unique way to proactively organize information using a mixture of automated and human-powered technologies.

Dr. Michel Biezunski works as a consultant and developer (under the name “Infoloom”) in the domain of Topic Maps. He has created and is still involved in a Topic Map used by IRS, called “TaxMap”. He is now developing a new generation of topic mapsfor libraries and academic publishers. Michel’s background is in history and philosophy of science.


Matt Broach 

Structuring Ethical Data

Axiologue is a crowd-sourced, community-based project that tracks the ethical histories of products and companies.  The goal is to create a single, comprehensive source that gives personalized rankings across all ethical categories: environment, labor, political, and more -- a one-stop information shop for the ethical consumer.  Our work raises a number of interesting Information Architecture concerns, including: how do you bring some kind of order to the vast (and conflicting) sources of information?  How do you make the translation from ethical information to ethical data?  How do you make information verifiable, reliable, and vandalism-resistant (in a crowd-sourced setting)?  This talk will explore some of Axiologue's (provisional) solutions to these questions.

Matt is a artist, teacher, activist, and developer.  His work has been show in galleries and film festivals in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Philadelphia, and New York.  As a video and interaction designer, he's worked with musicians such as Bruno Mars and Paramore and internationally recognized artists such as Glenn Ligon.  He currently teaches in the Digital Arts department at Pratt and runs the video/interaction design firm Aphasiac Design, while developing the Axiologue project with Chloë Bass and our fantastic Axiologue community.
results.name: IA Gateway & Enterprise IA

results.description:
This Meetup Mashup includes the following communities:


Axiologue: http://www.meetup.com/Axiologue/

Information Architecture: 

http://www.meetup.com/information_architecture/

Semiotics Web: http://www.meetup.com/SemioticsWeb/


Moderator: Chris Novell


Chris Novell has a B.Ed and MBA. She worked as an internal consultant at Chase Manhattan Bank and as an Oppenheimer Research Department assistant. She has also trained in the CERT program (Community Emergency Response Team).

She has developed some deep learning techniques and created some educational tools and likes to enable students to have what she describes as a "peak learning experience." She has observed that young children absorb more sound bites than most adults realize. Interaction Design concepts have inspired her to design interactive and participatory art. While digital solutions can be powerful, Chris notes that mechanical ones can be magical, too. She marvels at the learning opportunities that Meetup groups have created.


Speakers:

Nathaniel Davis

A New System. A New Architecture. A New Model.

Understanding, building and maintaining a digital ecosystem requires a broader meaning of the term “system architecture.” A system architecture must express more than the function of information technology (IT). It must include the architecture of our human engagement with technology and the context within which our human and technology interactions persist. As a result, a new reference model for system architecture is paramount.

In this talk, Nathaniel will discuss the organizational and collaborative challenges that business stakeholders, product managers, technologists, UI designers, usability engineers, user experience designers and information science professionals face to create and manage human-centered digital ecosystems. Nathaniel will propose a new model for digital experience architecture and call for digital professionals to advocate a new digital “system” that thrives on the coherent and thoughtful architecture of both design and infrastructure.

Nathaniel Davis is the author of the upcoming book “Information Architecture: Theory, Science and Practice” due in 2016. Nathaniel is a veteran of information architecture, web strategy and design. He advises on IA and UX strategy and is founder of the DSIA Research Initiative where he curates the DSIA Portal of Information Architecture - a public knowledge base of articles and resources based on his research. Nathaniel is the information architecture columnist for UXmatters and a contributing guest writer for the Bulletin of The Association for Information Science and Technology (ASIS&T). In addition to curating the DSIA Research Initiative, Nathaniel Davis serves as director of information architecture for a Fortune 100 company.

Noreen Whysel

results.description:
Our last Bowling Meetup sold out! And this might be our last one of the year so don't miss it!! 

MEN get tickets here - http://bit.ly/1JUHwnV

WOMEN get tickets here - http://bit.ly/1VGCdPF

Mix & mingle before bowling with ice breakers while we create teams. Women & Men will be paired into teams of two or three. Each team will stay together throughout the event.  

Next the fun begins.  A person from the female team will bowl a frame. Then a member of the male team will bowl a frame. The process continues until all 10 frames are bowled. The group that has the highest score of each game wins a prize!

At end of game, ladies will stay at the same lane. Male team will rotate to next lane and the process begins again. We will continue for either two hours or until you have met everyone.

You will have the option to complete a scorecard at the end of the night. You can write down the names of anyone you were interested in. We will send them an email letting them know that you were interested and provide your email address. 

What's included:

• Free Bowling Games, Shoe Rental & Scorecard Matching 

• Snacks & Ice Breakers

• Singles in their 20s, 30s, 40s

• Prizes for winning team

Tickets are $30-$35 depending upon how early you purchase:

MEN get tickets here - http://bit.ly/1JUHwnV

WOMEN get tickets here - http://bit.ly/1VGCdPF

Prepay Only Event - No tickets sold at door 

Can I still attend even If I don't want to bowl?  Yes, you can still be a member of the team and mingle.  Food & Drink will also be available for purchase. 

Can I come alone?  Yes, 80% attending come on their own. 

Why does your RSVP say +30?  This is a multi-Meetup, non-ethnic specific event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees.  About 40 singles will be attending ages, mostly 20s-40s. But all are welcome 21+.

How do I attend?  RSVP w/ group and purchase ticket here - http://www.weekenddating.com/upcoming.shtml?eventid=5931

results.description:
The new and fun way to find your new roommate. Whether you want to meet some people to find a new place with, or if you have a spare room you'd like to fill, this is a fun and social way to get it done.

Why sort through hundreds of e-mails to set up roommate interviews, only to get rejected?

Why spend an entire weekend letting strangers into your house?

It's a casual and fun event that allows you to have a drink with potential roommates and see if there is any roommate chemistry brewing. Best of all, there is no charge to come to the event. Yes, it's FREE.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll have a sign  on the table where we are sitting.
results.name: Mingle with Potential Roommates

results.description:

You are invited to our Aperitivo con amici. Bring your friends and stories to share! There is no participation fee, and the event is cash bar.

Riccardo & Walter

results.description:
Prepayment is required at http://www.weekenddating.com/upcoming.shtml?eventid=5931<a href="http://www.weekenddating.com/upcoming.shtml?eventid=5903"></a>

------------------------------------------------ 
WHAT: Speed BOWLING for Singles 

WHERE: Bowlmor Times Square 
WHO: Single men and women ages 20's, 30's, & 40's

How it works 
Women will be paired up into teams of two or three and Men will be paired up into teams of three. Don't worry if you are coming alone or do not have three people to sign up. People will arrive early so you will have time to mingle with ice breakers and we will help create the teams. Each team will stay together throughout the event.

Next the fun begins. We will have one male team and one female team stationed at each bowling lane. This male and female team (known as a group) will combine to bowl one 10 frame game. Remember, you are not bowling an entire game yourself. This is a group effort. A person from the female team will bowl a frame. Next, a member of the male team will bowl a frame. Then female number two bowls a frame followed by male number two. The process continues until all ten frames are bowled. During this time all of the members of the group will be getting to know each other. Which ever group has the highest score at the end of each game will win a prize.

At the end of the game, the ladies will stay at the same lane. The male team will rotate to the next lane and the process begins again. We will continue for either two hours or until you have met everyone.

Note: You can still attend and be a member of a team even if you do not want to bowl.


Includes: Bowling, Shoes and scorecard matching.


**************Food and Drinks are available for purchase********


Question: I was interested in someone but am still uncomfortable asking them for contact information.


You will have the option to complete a scorecard at the end of the night and take notes during the event. You can write down the names of anyone you were interested in from the event. We will send them an email letting them know that you were interested and provide your email address..

results.description:
Since its announcement in May 2014, Xamarin.Forms has excited the development community by allowing C# programmers to write cross-platform mobile applications that run on iOS, Android, and Windows Phone devices. Using both C# and XAML, programmers construct user interfaces and supporting code with a platform-independent API that then maps to native controls on these three platforms.

But Xamarin is also enthusiastic about F#. Although there is not yet a Visual Studio project template for directly creating Xamarin.Forms applications in F#, it's fairly easy to make hybrid C# and F# solutions that let you write the bulk of your application code in F#.

Join Charles Petzold in a code-heavy presentation as he demonstrates this technique, while also exploring some of the concepts and power of F#, including recursion, piping, and asynchronous processing.

Speaker

Charles Petzold is the author of several books on Windows programming, most notably Programming Windows, currently in its 6th edition and covering the Windows Runtime API. He is also the author of two books on the conceptual foundations of computing technology: Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software (Microsoft Press, 1999) and The Annotated Turing: A Guided Tour through Alan Turing's Historic Paper on Computability and the Turing Machine (Wiley, 2008)

Petzold is an employee of Xamarin where he is writing the book Creating Mobile Apps with Xamarin.Forms, available as a free download from xamarin.com. His web site is <a>www.charlespetzold.com.</a>

Note: This is a joint meeting with the NYC Mobile .NET Developers group. Please do NOT RSVP for both Meetups to make it easier for us to assess the attendee count.

Pizza will be provided courtesy of Xamarin.

Autumn is the perfect time to drink wines that pair perfectly with the foods of the Fall harvest! Taste 24 wines with the PINOT name, including favorites and other lesser-known grapes you will love to try. Enjoy a buffet of cheeses, hors d'oeuvres, and noshes with each sip! 

You will get a wine glass that you can have filled as many times as you'd like.  There are 3 tables or stations where they will be pouring the wines and explaining each one.  

Socialize and network in a relaxed atmosphere during one of our very popular walk around wine tasting events. Unlike other wine tastings where you are stuck at one table, this walk around format gives you the opportunity to easily meet other members and wine enthusiasts.  

You will enjoy up to 24 different wines all carefully explained by Vinoversity’s friendly and knowledgeable sommeliers. Tickets start at just $33 (price will go up as event gets closer).  

PREPAY ONLY EVENT. Must purchase ticket in advance at this link below (limited space and no tickets sold at door) - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/wine414/dates/Oct-27-2015_at_0630PM

What kinds of wine/apps?  24 whites, reds, sparklers, rose's, & dessert wines. These wines will not disappoint, and will amaze you with their unique flavors, styles, and mineralities. A super tasting from an incredible wine region! Complimentary cheeses, dips, olives, & flatbreads will be served. 

Can I come alone?  Yes 90%  attending come on their own. 

Do I need to know about wine? No, most come for socializing, learning and the enjoyment of wine.

What's dress code? Wear what you had on at work.  It is a casual and comfortable atmosphere. 

Who will be there? This is a multi-Meetup event so don't just go by RSVP's here. There will be 40+ others there.

What are the ages?  This is non-age specific event.  We'll have a good mix of ages 20s-50s. Everyone always seems to find people in their peer group to hang and taste with. 

Do I have to buy a ticket in advance?  Yes.  Space is limited and this will sell out. An RSVP alone will not hold your spot. You must purchase a ticket at this link to be confirmed - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/wine414/dates/Oct-27-2015_at_0630PM
results.name: Wine Tasting Social - Enjoy 24 Wines + Light Apps (PREPAY ONLY) Last one of year

Would you like to get a job as a Product Manager? Join us for this free open doors session to get an overview of our part-time product management course curriculum, meet the lead instructor and have the chance to ask any additional questions that you might have about what it takes to become a product manager in New York:

http://www.productschool.com/

All our classes are compatible with a regular work schedule and our campus is conveniently located in the heart of San Francisco. This is not your traditional lecture class. Expect a healthy mix of group work, one-­on-­ones with mentors, and a hands­-on experience building your own digital product from end to end.

The instructors are professionals with real-world experience working at renowned tech Companies like Google and LinkedIn, and other technology startups.

We have assembled a list of local hiring partners who are eagerly looking for our top Product School students.

Timeline: 

6:30 - 6:45 pm - Meet & Greet

6:45 - 7:15 pm - Info Session

7:15 - 7:30 pm - Q & A      

• *snacks & refreshments will be provided


Takeaways:

• Meet the Product School Team and potential classmates

• Get an overview of the curriculum and course objectives

• Meet the Lead Instructor and hear about his background

• Have the chance to ask Product School Alumni questions about their experience

Meet the Instructors: 

Carlos González de Villaumbrosia is the CEO of Product School. He has 8 years of experience building teams and digital products on 3 continents. He is a three times company Co-founder. Before Product School, he was the Lead Instructor of Product Management at General Assembly and Co-founder and CEO of Floqq (invested by 500Startups), the biggest marketplace for online video courses in Latin America.

</a>

<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/rayyanislam">Rayyan Islam is VP of Product Product at Beacon and Investor at early-stage startups. He has worked with companies like Spotify, 406 Ventures, Lazard, and Deloitte to drive lasting impact and value to technology startups and enterprises. He is also the Product Management Instructor at Product School in New York.

results.description:
On October 27, we’d like to invite you to see the New Knowledge Organization process in action!


6:30- Mingling with fellow HIPSters

7:00- Panel begins

7:45- Mingling with panelists over free pizza & beer

Facilitated by Vyjayanthi Vadrevu and Phil Surles, the NewKnowledge team will discuss and workshop a project proposal to help inmates develop practical job skills for re-entering the workforce while simultaneously addressing the need for endangered species propagation, and understanding the systemic changes needed to support skilled workers in their life beyond prison. Join us to hear New Knowledge researchers share how each of their perspectives in human rights, anthropology, clinical psychology, conservation, animal behavior, and economic development contributes unique insight. 

~.~.

New Knowledge Organization Ltd. is a nonprofit charitable think tank that pursues understanding and solutions for the challenges that face our society. With offices in New York and California and an extended team in Chicago, Philadelphia and Washington, the organization conducts independent research, evaluation, and planning support to help organizations contribute to the public good in the areas of wellness, media, culture, and the biosphere. With 25 staff and research fellows, NewKnowledge is a highly collaborative, transdisciplinary team of psychologists, sociologists, biologists, anthropologists, and social workers. Our strength lies in applying insights gained from multiple initiatives focused on similar topics viewed from varying perspectives. With every project, we aim to increase our partners’ effectiveness and efficiency. Ultimately, we seek to advance collective social knowledge, positive lived experiences, ecological harmony, and increased public engagement in solving society’s grand challenges.


~.~.

WeWork, the platform for creators, has opened its first Brooklyn location - DUMBO Heights and it is growing strong.  With weekly events, personalized support, flexibility, and access to thousands of like-minded entrepreneurs, small businesses, and freelancers around the world - WeWork is the perfect place to grow your business in 2015. To learn more about joining the community, visit the website, email [masked], or call[masked] and let them know you were referred by Jessica Clark.

results.description:
"What we observe is not nature itself, but nature exposed to our method of questioning.” ― Werner Heisenberg

Does the act of measuring something invariably change it? It would seem that in the case of news in the digital age, the answer is a clear and unambiguous ... sometimes.

Pro Journos in NY is delighted to welcome: 

• Caitlin B. Petre, who, under a fellowship at Columbia's Tow Center for Digital Journalism, went inside the New York Times and Gawker Media and looked at how they use sophisticated audience metrics in the newsroom. Her report can be found here.

• Helen Havlak, engagement editor at The Verge. She oversees audience development, social media, SEO, and analytics and is responsible for growing audiences both on and off platform.

Don't miss this one! The topic of analytics in the newsroom is much more than an interesting theoretical question; it has very real implications for anyone looking to make a career in media today.
results.how_to_find_us: South side of 39th, b/t Fifth and Sixth Aves.
results.name: Panel Discussion: How Analytics Inform Newsrooms and the News

results.description:
Event agenda: 

6:30 - 7:00 PM: Networking & Food 
7:00 - 7:30 PM: Hilary's talk
7:30 - 8:00 PM: Kevin's talk
8:30 - 9:00 PM: Socializing

Hilary's talk:

Adaptive learning technology is used to provide personalized learning experiences for students. A common implementation provides individualized follow-up assignments for struggling students.   Using observed data, we show how to use bootstrapping and rejection sampling to create a valid comparative study of groups of students who do and don’t use adaptive technology, even when the samples are not uncorrelated.

Hillary Green-Lerman is a member of the research team at Knewton. As a data scientist at Knewton, she designs and implements studies that provide quantitative evidence of the potential of Knewton-powered products to improve student learning outcomes. Previously, Hillary worked as a scientific associate at D.E. Shaw Research, where she performed large-scale molecular dynamics simulations of protein-drug interactions on the Anton supercomputers, and published her findings in Nature. She holds a B.S. in Materials Science and Engineering from the University of California, Berkeley. Previously, she has spoken at NYC Python Meetup, Biophysical Society, and Protein Society, and has written about women in STEM for Lilith Magazine.


Kevin's talk:

A common problem faced by the NBA and Knewton are evaluating (groups of) people's skills. The NBA cares about who is the best basketball team. Knewton cares whether or not you have mastered a particular skill. These problems may be modeled in strikingly similar ways. In this talk, we step through why these situations may be modeled so similarly as well as how their different evaluation metrics affect our confidence in the models' performance.


Kevin Wilson is a principal data scientist at Knewton. During his tenure there, he has helped build, implement, and evaluate the proficiency and other models which serve millions of students using Knewton's recommendation engine. Before Knewton, he received his PhD in mathematics from Princeton and his bachelor's in mathematics from the University of Michigan.
results.how_to_find_us: Please ask for Knewton downstairs and security will direct you. The event is taking place on the 8th floor.
results.name: Data Science at Knewton

group.name: NYC Women in Machine Learning & Data Science

Whether you are just beginning to think about taking the leap or you're in the middle of the process, it is easy to get overwhelmed. How do you know when to leave your current role and how do you best position yourself for your next?

Get insights into making the transition from experienced and successful Product Managers in this panel discussion.

Takeaways:

Understand the role and importance of product managers in today's tech industry.

Get insight into what you need to make a transition into product management.

Get introduced to the product management community in NYC.

Timeline:
6:30 - 6:45 pm - Meet & Greet
6:45 - 7:15 pm - Panel Discussion
7:15 - 7:30 pm - Q & A
*wine & refreshments will be provided

Who is this workshop for:

• Software engineers who want to transition to Product Management • MBAs with a finance/consulting background who want to work in high tech companies as a Product Manager Project Managers, Marketers, Designers who are seeking for new opportunities in Product Management Meet the Moderator
Carlos is CEO at Product School. He has 7 years of experience building teams and digital products on 3 Continents. He is a three times company Co-founder. Before Product School, he was the Lead Instructor of Product Management at General Assembly and Co-founder and CEO of Floqq (invested by 500Startups), the biggest marketplace for online video courses in Latin America.
results.name: Product Management Course - Info Session

results.description:
We are happy to invite back Thomas Levine for this month's meetup.

About the talk:

Every day when I wake up, I ask myself "Would I rather be sleeping?" If the answer is yes, I go back to sleep. Once in a while I wake up, and sometimes I even program something. And once I'm tired of that, I go back to sleep, regardless of whether the programming is finished. This work schedule lends itself to a style of programming that efficiently produces robust, simple, user-friendly data analysis software.

I'll introduce the main principles behind my approach to writing data analysis software. Next, I'll present some common problems that my programming style completely avoids. Finally, I'll discuss how my programming style is well suited for certain projects and horribly inappropriate for others.


Some main ideas include:

• I store the most raw form of data that I can, and then I think of my entire program as pure functions. To make it easy to store raw forms of data, I wrote vlermv, a library that maps Python dictionaries to files.

• Systems should be so simple and legible that I can figure out how they worked after I have lost the source code and the documentation and only have the data.

• I have a particular way of drawing flow charts. Based on what the flow chart looks like, I can identify problems with the design of the software.


About Tom:

Thomas Levine is a neodadaist. In addition to sleep, he is interested in multisensory data plots, "data", and letterpress printing. He writes frequently; popular works include a shell testing framework, research on the publishing of government open data, a spreadsheet-based music sequencer, tutorials and discussions on data, and a study on the vicious hovering cycle of toilet usage.


Pizza starts at 6:30, the talk begins at 7 and then we'll go to a local bar.
results.name: Ten strange engineering practices for robust & intuitive data science workflows

WHAT: Speed BOWLING NYC- AGES 20's, 30's, 40's (prepay required)


WHERE: Bowlmor Times Square 
WHO: AGES 20's, 30's, 40's (prepay required)

How it works

Women will be paired up into teams of two or three and Men will be paired up into teams of three. We will have one male team and one female team stationed at each bowling lane. This male and female team (known as a group) will combine to bowl one 10 frame game. Remember, you are not bowling an entire game yourself. This is a group effort. A person from the female team will bowl a frame. Next, a member of the male team will bowl a frame. Then female number two bowls a frame followed by male number two. The process continues until all ten frames are bowled. During this time all of the members of the group will be getting to know each other. Which ever group has the highest score at the end of each game will win a prize. Please visit http://www.weekenddating.com/bowling.shtml for full details on this special format and scorecard matching.

The topic for this week's discussion is Introduction and Chapter 1: The Neophyte Entering on the Path.

You can download the book free here!

About the Book

The Technique of the Disciple is a book containing a modem description of the ancient esoteric path to spiritual illumination, trod by the masters and avatars of yore. It has long been said that Christ left, as a great heritage to members of His secret council, a private method for guidance in life, which method has been preserved until today in the secret, occult, mystery schools.

In this book, Raymund Andrea has created a masterful account of the challenges and rewards awaiting those who dare to venture on the ancient path to mystical awakening. He reveals the method for attaining a greater life taught in these mystery schools, which perhaps parallels the secret instructions of Christ to members of His council.

All are Welcome!

NEO-ERICKSONIAN HYPNOSIS PRACTICE GROUP – Join us for our regular on-going Practice Group and become the best damn hypnotist you can be!

*Every second and forth Tuesday evening of the month. Continues May 12th and 26th for 2 hours, 7 PM to 9 PM at the TRS Suites in New York City.

Each meeting will focus on something new or in need of practice so we can improve our skills and expand our range. We’ll watch videos of Milton Erickson in action and take the time to dissect them and really learn from them. You’ll learn and share new techniques. We’ll swap scripts. We’ll swap books and other media. Above all, we’ll PRACTICE and get GOOD.

One benefit you get from attending is the group support of learning. Last time we met we watched a couple of hours of a newly available DVD set called “In the Room with Milton Erickson.” It’s how Erickson taught Ericksonian Hypnosis. Up to maybe a dozen people would squeeze into his office and listen to him speak and watch him do demos. Now YOU can be in that room too. It’s pretty amazing, really, and SO instructive. I love it.

He can help YOU, too.

results.description:
Anyone up for a moonlit walk at Sandy Hook on Tuesday-Yes, Tuesday- on October 27?  We will meet at the first parking lot at Fort Hancock and start walking at 7pm.  We will walk along Sandy Hook Bay, and over to a look out point where we can see the NYC skyline.  After that, who knows where our flashlights will take us!  It may be a little chilly, but we'll keep moving to keep warm.  Don't forget your flashlights!

We will meet at Fort Hancock, which is 4 miles down the road after passing thru the main ticket booths. There is no charge anymore to enter.  When you come to the 2nd set of rockets, you will come to a fork in the road, stay to the right and the parking lot will be on your left. We will start the walk at 7:00.

After the walk, we will head over to Tommy's Tavern in Sea Bright on Ocean Ave. for a bite to eat. 

Heavy rain will cancel this walk, but the weather is looking good so far.

Please leave your four legged friends at home.  After all, it will be a full moon..... and we don't need any howling at the moon!!
results.name: Full Moon Walk at Sandy Hook

This week I am going to see Steve Jobs I will arrive at 7:00 for the 7:30 pm showing. I  have seat E11 If you are coming post your seat #  Also if anyone wants to we can go to the  Red Oak Diner after the show for snack, just meet in the lobby after to discuss.

Hope to see YOU!  Love, Cassie

Ok who LOVES the movies as much as me? Who has a limited entertainment budget like me? LOL Well this is the event for YOU!

My local theater has discount Tuesday every week and if you sign up online they will even send you a coupon for the concession stand, each week a different one (this weeks is free small popcorn with a drink purchase). They also have those awesome new reclining seats! And you get to choose and pay for your seat in advance so there is no rushing in at the last minute and sitting in the front row and straining your neck!  Here is the link to the theater for more details: http://www.cinemark.com/theatre-detail.aspx?node_id=83854

So here is how it's going to work each week. I will choose a movie when the new schedule goes out (Fri/Sat) and choose the movie and showtime. I will buy my seat online and post what row and number. Those of you who wish to join me can buy your seat near me. There are two ways to buy seats: 1) online in advance is your best bet but there is a $1.25 service fee per ticket unless you buy a gift card at the theater and pre-load it 2) At the theater no service fee but you really need to drive there in advance if you want seats near us. OR you can just show up that night and sit wherever there is space available.

Hope to see YOU at the movies!!    Love, Cassie

PS: I am doing this with my friendship group too so if you are S&L do wear your wristbands. If you need to buy one let me know, they are just $1 These are loads of fun at the movies though they glow in the dark!

if you can't make it, no need to post why. We understand and will catch you next time!

results.description:
Maximize your potential with Russian Martial Arts!

CONQUER THE FEAR of a violent encounter.

INCREASE YOUR STRIKING POWER and learn practical self defense methods that will work ANYTIME, ANYWHERE


Develop a STRONG, FLEXIBLE, MOBILE PHYSIQUE and MENTAL FOCUS that will carry over into every aspect of your life.


Learn all this and much, much more at NJ RMA Self Defense Group, the official Meetup Group of System of Combat NJ.  Start your FALL with with Russian Martial Arts, your first class is FREE.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1tm6NW32NdI


Enjoy your first class for free and after that, it is only $10 per class with discounts available for pre-payment. No contract required! Classes are held at 7:00pm on Tuesday and Thursday evenings at the YMHA OF UNION on 501 Green Lane, Union, NJ 07083.

About Us

If you are interested in Systema, Reality Based Self Defense,  Martial Arts, Grappling, Street Defense, or Mobility and Body Awareness, this is the Meetup Group for you.  Men and women, seasoned martial artists and raw beginners alike will benefit from our dynamic classes which are tailored to the level and needs of the students. We focus on providing comprehensive instruction, plenty of personal attention and a relaxed atmosphere where you can train at your own pace and intensity. Individual classes are fast-paced and varied, ranging in subject from striking mechanics, grappling and ground fighting, evasive movement, weapon defense, sparring, and dealing with multiple attackers to women's self defense and street safety.
Copyright © 2013 System of Combat NJ                                   

About Systema

Systema is a combat style based on ancient Slavic fighting methods which were collected and codified by the Russian Soviet special forces.  It is a devastatingly effective and versatile combative program that can easily stand alone, or augment your existing practice.  The overarching focus is on responding to a threat spontaneously with natural, instinctive movement which strengthens and restores the body, clarifies the mind, and provides a framework for healthy, safe, life-long activity 

About the instructor 

Jim has over 25 years of martial arts experience in various styles including Brazilian Jiu-jitsu (BJJ), Silat, Boxing, Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) and Karate.  He is certified to teach Systema by Alex Wilkie (Alex Wilkie's Martial Arts Academy).

Directions

When you arrive, let the front desk know you are there for the martial arts class and they will direct you. (You do not have to be a Y-member to attend this class).  For general inquiries or more information, message organizers Jimi D or Drew here on the Meetup page.  If you need to reach the instructor, Jim, for any reason, call

results.description:
Our Tuesday night Central Park training workouts are typically tempo runs or hill repeats.  These workouts are usually very well attended with a wide variety of paces.

The meeting spot is at the 72nd street transverse by Bethesda Fountain. There we'll give the full workout details, including distance, pacing groups, expected run time, and where we plan on meeting at the end. You can expect a typical workout to be between 5 and 8 miles (or less during hill workouts).

A note on warm ups: We do not do a full warm up as a group in Central Park, so we encourage you to show up at 7 p.m. having jogged an easy mile or two ahead of time. 


If it's your first time meeting us, feel free to come a few minutes early with any questions.  There are many other groups who meet on 72nd St so look for the one with folks in Whippet singlets.

Please note that there is no place to store bags inside Central Park. Pack light, or store your bags at a nearby gym if you are a member. Another option is the New York Running Company at the Time Warner Center, which stays open until 9pm: http://www.therunningcompany.net/new-yorks-homepage
results.how_to_find_us: We meet on 72nd transverse at the point that overlooks Bethesda Fountain
results.name: Central Park Training Run

Bring a project and get to work, drink a homebrew beer, hang out, and draw on advice from our wonderful community.

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

No fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP 24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

Name of the school William J. O’Shea (100W): The school entrance is located on West 77th street between Columbus and Amsterdam avenues (pretty much in the middle of the block) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right), Please wait and someone will open the door for you.  the court is on the second floor. 

For questions: Use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

Maidsafe holds the distinction of being one of the first companies to put Rust into production, and boy did they do it in a big way.  

They have built a secure, distributed computation platform that aims to change how the internet creates and deploys applications.

To conquer the challenges of building trustworthy and fast distributed algorithms + a healthy dose of crypto, they opted for Rust and immediately saw huge improvements in code succinctness and reliability. 

Paige Peterson is visiting from the left coast to share the story of Maidsafe and how using it will lead to utter awesomeness.  There might be time at the end of a mini-hackathon, so bring your laptops!

The meetup will be hosted by Jim's company, Spring.  They are kind enough to not only provide seats and a projector screen, but also food and beverages! 

To get to Spring, just head to  162 5th Ave.  Tell the folks at the lobby desk that you're there for the Spring Meetup, and they'll direct you to the elevator for the 3rd floor.

results.description:
Orly Krasner will call a lovely program of English country dance with live musical accompaniment.

Come dance to a live caller and band with Country Dance New York.  We are an intergenerational, multiethnic, smoke and alcohol free, inclusive community with one thing in common:  we love to contra and English country dance! 

English country dance is choreographed community dancing, with repertoire ranging from court dances of the 1650s through dances composed this year. If you’ve seen any of the Jane Austen movies, you’ve glimpsed some kinds of ECD.

Please bring a pair of clean, soft soled shoes {no spike heels} to dance in, and a water bottle.  We ask that you not use strongly scented grooming products as the smell can become overwhelming on the dance floor when things start to heat up. 

Country Dance New York has been hosting contra dances most Saturdays, and English country dancing most Tuesdays, at Church of the Village for almost 70 years.   COV is located at 201 W. 13 St., on the northwest corner of 7th Avenue.  

Beginners' session on Saturdays {for contra} is from 7:30 to 8:00.  Dancing for all from 8:00 until 10:45.  Hang out with us at a local diner after the dance.

Beginner's session on Tuesdays {for ECD} is from 7:00 to 7:30.  Dancing for all from 7:30 to 10:30.

Cost:  $15 for general public; $12 members and for full time students with ID.  Be sure to tell the people at the door if this is your first time dancing with us.  They will give you a free pass to return as our guest! 

To see what contra dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mM5vNzFxxBs 

To see what English country dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rB40AvJnMUY 

Join us on Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/2449906414/

For a complete schedule of our upcoming season, and for more information, visit our website.

See you on the dance floor!
results.name: English Country Dance with Orly Krasner!

results.description:
Check out our website:   www.NYCommunityChoir.com for  more information and to pre-pay for sessions and save money.

LOCATION
520 Eighth Avenue - 16th Floor


Join us monthly on Tuesdays for a soulful and uplifting musical experience that’s designed to include anyone who loves to sing – shower singers and professionals alike. 

Our sessions incorporate vocal technique training, choral singing, music-oriented meditation, community and relationship building activities, creative play, and musical improvisation and games all within a supportive, non-judgmental family environment. 

Music selections are soulful, spirit-driven Gospel, Broadway, Spiritual, World Music, chanting, Pop/Rock with lyrics that are universally accessible to people of any religious belief (no He, Him or Jesus). 

Each session is co-taught by industry seasoned professionals: Artistic Director, Amy Silverman, a wonderful accompanist Emily Imes, and, at most sessions, we also have a guest powerhouse musical director. We’re lucky to have many talented and in-demand musical directors and conductors who feel committed to our success and growth. 

Plan to be musically guided and inspired by the leadership of  Lesley Kernochan, Troy Burton, Chris Dilley and other fantastic surprise guest conductors.


===================================

WHAT TO EXPECT:

Choir Rehearsal + Jam Session + Singing Technique Training + Expressive Creative Activities + Amazing Family-like Supportive Community of People Who Love to Sing + Conscious, Spiritual and Soulful Approach + Professional, Dynamic Leaders


===================================

WHAT PARTICIPANTS HAVE SAID:

"Amy, words can't express (maybe I can sing it???) the amount of love and gratitude I have for you and everyone for participating last night. The experience was powerful, healing and joyful. I felt whole and complete in my voice in a way I've never felt before. I've always wanted to sing but haven't had the opportunity to really pursue. It's great the Universe has brought me this one that feels perfect. What a great combination of community building and sharing our hearts through song. I was very moved and can't wait to come back. Much love to you all!!" - Doug Larson

"It was an amazing experience, thank you very much for putting this all together. Ive been looking for a space like this, to express myself, for a long time and I cant believe I found it!!!! I'm looking forward to our next gathering. Thanks again!!!" - Vicky Vernier

===================================

REGISTRATION AND LOGISTICS

What does it cost?

$10 for first time guests (pay in person)


$25 pay in person
$22 pay in advance online

And discounted packages are available when you pay for 5, 10, 15 or all of the sessions in a group.


===================================


QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

Do I have to commit to coming all the time?
Nope - just come check us out - we hope you'll want to come consistently but there's room for everyone, even drop-ins!

Do I have to be a "singer"?
No - you just have to love to sing!

What do I need to bring?
Voice recorder or Smart Phone
Water Bottle
Open mind and heart
Desire to sing and connect playfully


I can't attend, how do I find out more about future opportunities?

Send an email to  [masked]  and say "please add me to your mailing list!"


I'm keeping everyone updated in the NY "I Love To Sing" Community Choir Group 
https://www.facebook.com/groups/529840427030696/?ref=ts&fref=ts

results.description:
Pictorial Photographers of America (PPA) is open to photographers - professional, amateur, and beginner - of all levels. Founded by Clarence H. White in 1916, it is one of NYC's oldest photography clubs.

We meet at 7:00OPM on the 2nd and 4th Tuesdays of the month at 346 West 20th Street (between 8th& 9th), St. Peter’s Church Rectory in Chelsea.

You can contact us at: [masked]

One meeting per month is usually a presentation by a photo professional, and one is a members' competition (digital and print categories) critiqued and judged by a professional.

Visitors are very welcome.

Please join us this Tuesday, October 27th at 7:00PM.  The presentation is being given by Paul S. Stetzer, Jr.

Paul has ended one career and begun another.  His first profession was education, beginning in Head Start in 1968. He then became an environmental educator at an urban nature center and concluded as an elementary science teacher in a Quaker school. After spending all his life in Philadelphia teaching and raising two daughters, he married his childhood sweetheart and moved to New York in 1997 where he helped to raise two stepdaughters. Time passes as it is wont to do, and currently he has the great joy of being companion to two grandchildren. Now, Paul practices photography: landscape, portrait, and documentary. Travel has afforded the opportunity to make photographs in wonderful wild places .Everywhere are people who stand willingly before Paul’s camera. Being in New York City provides many lessons in democracy, like Occupy Wall Street, to serve as focus for the camera. In addition, he has found an exhibition outlet in the in the photographically diverse community of Soho Photo Gallery where he currently serves as president.


Pictorial Photographers of America will be celebrating their 100th anniversary next year in 2016.


We look forward to seeing everyone!

• Extract your pattern guide into a reusable package. 

• The basics for you Sass Pattern Guide

• Setting up a linter 

• Separating our your folders 

• Identify repeating elements 

• Deciding the best way to package your front end for your company/team 

• A review of gems/npm/grunt 

• Setting up a new project for your extracted pattern guide 

• Tips for displaying your pattern guide and why it’s important 

• Hosting tips 

• Determining how changes will be merged back into your pattern guide from submissions

• Including your pattern guide into old and new projects

Ideally, I want everyone to walk out with their own skeletal beginning of a pattern guide. I be providing a dummy website to work with through the exercises. It will be important for them to apply the skills to their own code base afterwards, but the highest bang for their buck will be to follow along in class, see and answer and be able to work from there.

All material will be printed out and resources available ahead of time to give attendees different ways of working through the material to assist best in their method of learning.

There will be 3 exercises, one worked together as a class, one as individuals, and then paired exercise.

Who is this for?
Anyone in a company looking to compartmentalize like styles and needs to communicate with designers or other developers.

What do I mean by portable pattern guide?
You site styles might need to be included across sites/projects and you want to compartmentalize your assets/styles/brand so that it can get the widest use.
results.name: The Portable Pattern Guide with Rachel Ober

results.description:
IMPROV FOR ACTORS - There's No "I" in Ensemble

This Improve with Improv workshop will focus on working as an ensemble. Whether you're playing a principal role, a supportive role, or even if you're off stage, you are still part of a team and have a role to play.

You will engage in group exercises, games and scenes that train the performer to give and take the spotlight, to stay engaged and involved in what is going on on stage, and to work as a team.

A fun safe and non-competitive environment is created in which each participant will learn how to work through inhibitions and tap into their imaginations.

Suggested Donation: $15*


*free drink with $15 donation

**most improv classes in NYC cost $35-$50 or more per session**


THE BENEFITS OF IMPROV


Improv can help you reduce stage fright, perform with more ease, increase your emotional range, build rapport with your scene partners, and have more fun on stage.

Many actors get “stuck in their heads” and as a result feel paralyzed and/or disconnected when performing. Improv skills give the actor tools that will get them out of their heads and into the scene.
results.name: There's No "I" in Ensemble

results.description:
In this group, you'll learn new ways of communicating in order to share more vulnerably and openly, bring attention more fully to the present in order to discover the richness of whats happening in relationship with others, and begin to see and co-explore aspects of yourself you may have been unaware of before in service of greater self-understanding, expression and awareness. You'll have the opportunity to learn and use new tools to participate in circles by sharing yourself, understanding others, and growing in both enjoyment of and capacity for presence and deep connection.

The more Ive seen people Circle the more genuine, " in the moment" conversations Ive seen become possible for them.

Likewise, the more Ive seen them become comfortable in their own skin, get clear on what their feeling, wanting or needing in any moment, grow in a sense of presence and natural interest in others, and generally embody a deep capacity for presence and authenticity.

If connecting profoundly with others, developing present moment awareness, and learning new communication skills inspires you, come try Circling out! The cost is $20
results.name: Tuesday Night Circling: Creating Connection and Presence

results.description:
*PLEASE NOTE THAT RSVP AND ID ARE REQUIRED TO ENTER*

Earlier this month, the Court of Justice of the European Union invalidated the much relied upon "safe harbor" permitting transfers of EU personal data to many United States companies. Fueled in large part by Edward Snowden's disclosures on NSA surveillance, the decision means that EU law no longer recognizes one of the primary ways for enabling transfers of personal data. Almost 5,000 companies now must look for alternative ways under EU law to legitimize transfers that are today an integral part of daily commerce.

The case also throws into question a number of other methods used in the EU to enable free flows of data, and recent statements from regulators and policymakers both within and without the EU have only further complicated the picture.

This event will look at the impact of a world with no Safe Harbor, the possible alternatives available, as well as the growing trend in countries implementing EU-style restrictions on the transfer of data.

Speakers TBA
results.name: Safe Harbor R.I.P.: A Data Protection Postmortem

results.description:
Open Office Hours

Meeting every Tuesday evening, 7:00PM - 10:00PM

This month's host: Codesters (http://blog.codesters.com/)


Office hours is open to developers of any background and skill level. Newcomers to programming, Python, or NYC are all welcome, as well as experienced programmers and locals. The purpose of this event is to promote learning and community involvement within the NYC Python community.

Activities vary and may include (but are not limited to):

Informal tech talks: Topics can be anything related to Python or programming. Have a topic you'd like to see presented? Leave a comment starting with "Talk topic suggestion". Want to present? Message the organizers.

Technical discussions: Bring your code and / or questions about any relevant topic, and there will most likely be someone present who can help. For questions about a specific topic, please leave a comment in the form of "Need help with Django / Nginx / SQL". If you're able to help with a particular topic, please leave a comment in the form of "Can help with Flask / Apache / NoSQL".

Note: Recruiting and other solicitation are not allowed at these events. These are run for developers by developers. Behavior that makes others uncomfortable will not be tolerated, and offenders will be asked to leave.

Profuse thanks go to our sponsors for loaning us this space and providing refreshments.

Thank you, and see you Tuesday night!
results.name: Tuesday Office Hours

results.description:
A Course in Miracles Healing Clinic at CRS
 Mon. & Tue. 7 – 7:40 pm
Sun 1 – 2 pm (12 – 1 pm on 2nd Sun of the month)
Suggested donation $20. No one is turned away.

Bring any issue you are facing right now — physically, emotionally, mentally, and/or spiritually. With eyes closed (you will be seated and a healer will stand nearby; no touching is involved), a CRS healer, trained in A Course in Miracles and spiritual reading/healing, will observe you with his inner sight, free of any judgments, as your truly are, a perfect shining spirit. Together, will ask the Holy Spirit (or Inner Guide if you prefer) to bring us directly to whatever seed thought is causing your current issues and ask for guidance about how your spirit really wants to make use of your present situation for its growth and sharing of love. After about 10 minutes of meditation, we will share the inspirational guidance that we receive. 

Aside from sharing the message that we receive from the Holy Spirit, we don't talk during this meetup event. We share healing quietly and provide you with an opportunity to come to rest, reflect, and remember who you truly are, in a supportive, non-judgmental, meditative environment.

We'd like to offer you an opportunity to experience stillness of mind and peace so that you can return to harmony with your true nature and purpose. Then you will find that rather than needing "solutions" to "problems" you will realize that you have no problems except those that you project.

We call this spiritual healing but it is not religious nor connected with any church or group. It is simply a practice of meditating together on our true nature and connecting with universal spirit/energy or what you will.

A Note About the Role of Words in Healing: "Strictly speaking, words play no part at all in healing. The motivating factor is prayer, or asking. What you ask for you receive. But this refers to the prayer of the heart, not to the words you use in praying. Sometimes the words and the prayer are contradictory; sometimes they agree. It does not matter. God does not understand words, for they were made by separated minds to keep them in the illusion of separation. Words can be helpful, particularly for the beginner, in helping concentration and facilitating the exclusion, or at least the control, of extraneous thoughts. Let us not forget, however, that words are but symbols of symbols. They are thus twice removed from reality...." — A Course in Miracles Manual for Teachers, Section 21

"Since only the mind can be sick, only the mind can be healed. Only the mind is in need of healing." —"PSYCHOTHERAPY: Purpose, Process and Practice,"Supplements to A Course in Miracles
results.how_to_find_us: CRS is located one block east of Broadway and one and a half blocks south of Union Square, above Think Coffee shop.
results.name: Walk-In Spiritual Healing Clinic

Let's get together for some game night shenanigans! Our hope is you will get to know some interesting people all the while having fun playing games!


At 7:00pm we're going to kick things off with some open "quirk starters" as everyone is arriving, and at 7:30pm we'll split off into groups and play some games! 

The Uncommons is what happens when you combine board games with a cafe. It's only $5 per person (they take cash or card) for literally walls of games - as many as you want for as long as you want! They also have a menu with food and drinks of all sorts if desired.


Cards Against Humanity is always a group favorite at some point, and I'm probably going to try out a new game never before played just to spice things up. So whether, you're looking to make a ruckus with a classic or shake things up with something new, there's a game for all styles of interest!

I can't wait for us to get together and play  :-)

results.description:
We will be meeting at Info Commons in room#4.

PLEASE NOTE that we limit attendance to better insure that all get a chance to have their writing critiqued.  If our maximum for the week is reached, you have the option of being notified when someone changes their RSVP to no.  PLEASE DO NOT RSVP YES UNLESS YOU ARE AS SURE AS IS HUMANLY POSSIBLE THAT YOU WILL BE ABLE TO ATTEND AND CHANGE YOUR RSVP TO NO IMMEDIATELY if your situation does change, for the sake of those waiting for a spot.  


Join us for a weekly get together of sometimes frank and hopefully always constructive criticism of your literary work. There is no restriction on the type of genre and only a few rules:

1. Bring up to 6 double spaced typed pages of your work for reading. Additional copies would be helpful in order to allow others in the group to follow along.

2. The author is not allowed to speak while feedback is being provided.

3. The same piece should not be reread at a future workshop.

We will meet every Tuesday at 7 PM on the first floor of the Central Library, unless a meetup is not scheduled for that date due to a holiday or other event. A floor plan link is available at http://www.brooklynpubliclibrary.org/sites/default/files/files/pdf/central/floorplan.pdf.

More information about the Brooklyn Central Library, including available public transportation options, can be found at http://www.brooklynpubliclibrary.org/locations/central.

Hope to see all of you there.

David
results.name: David's Writers Workshop

In this session you will learn how to connect the Arduino to a few sensors (temperature and light) and outputs (servo motor and led) and control (outputs) or monitor(sensors) remotely.  Types of communications to be covered are Infrared, bluetooth, serial, I2C, and internet.

Reviews from our previous courses:


• "Awesome! I'd definitely go to a follow-up."

• "Great workshop, just the right touch to whet my appetite."

Requirements

We will provide laptops and Arduinos for participants.

About The Rockland County Makerspace and CILK119
This course is hosted by the Rockland County Makerspace @CILK119 (www.cilk119.com), a co-working space located in Nanuet, NY.  

Dr. Duncan Bell is a life-long tinkerer who graduated from making go-karts and skateboards to designing industrial robots that support pharmaceutical research. Along the way he earned a PhD in Botany and Biophysics and conducted research in Scotland, Italy, and the United States in photosynthesis, cancer, and arthritis. In addition to spreading the word about the fantastic capabilities of the current generation of microcontrollers, he heads up a small company that develops custom storefront displays with coordinated motion and lighting—all driven by Arduinos. Recently, his Arduino-based float was a prize winner at the Nyack Halloween parade and his Persistence of Vision special effect was featured in Elmwood Playhouse’s recent production of “Sunday in the Park with George.” 

Attendees at a recent Arduino Course

results.description:
Are you looking to land your dream job as a software engineer or web developer? Join Josh Goldstein, Co-Founder, and Brett Langdon, Senior Software Engineer, from Underdog.io, for a candid talk about what companies are looking for in engineers from the hiring manager's perspective. Underdog.io is a curated marketplace for talent that connects candidates with top tech startups. Come with questions about resumes, cover letters, profiles, portfolios, and personal branding and learn techniques to distinguish yourself as a candidate.

Josh Goldstein is the Co-Founder of Underdog.io, a curated marketplace for talent. Before Underdog.io, Josh was the first hire and Director of Operations at Bondsy, a mobile app to trade things with friends. Bondsy was backed by Thrive Capital and went through the Spring 2012 TechStars NYC class. 

Josh has an MBA from University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, where he also interned at Southern Capital Ventures, a Raleigh-based VC firm. He has a BA from Emory University in Atlanta.


Brett Langdon is a Senior Software Engineer at Underdog.io where he uses Python and Node.js to develop internal tools to help make Josh’s life better. Before Underdog.io Brett worked as a Software Engineer at Shapeways, the leading 3d printing marketplace and community.

Brett has always been apart of the engineering hiring process at every company he has worked at and has done everything from resume reviewing, phone screening, and interviewing of candidates of all levels (interns, junior, and senior engineers). When he isn’t writing code or reviewing candidates for Underdog.io, Brett is usually found cooking/baking, or working on a plethora of open source projects.
results.name: What hiring managers look for: Stand out from the pack with Underdog.io

Questions/Scriptures to be discussed include:

1. Why does God permit so much evil in the world?
2. What does mankind's future look like, as per the Bible?
3. Are science and faith mutually exclusive? Could they be reconciled with each other?
4. What happens when a man dies?
5. What has happened over 2000 years of church history and how has that changed Christianity from its original version?
6. Can the Bible be harmonized from Genesis to Revelation? Does it contradict itself anywhere?
7. What is the Kingdom of Heaven?
8. Why did Jesus tell so many parables (more than 90%) about his upcoming Kingdom?
9. What's the purpose of this Kingdom of God?
10. Why is it taking so long to come? Hasn't it been 2000 years since Jesus?
results.name: Tuesday Evening Bible Study (Newport)

results.description:
Greeting BK Techies!  We hope you've been having a great start of the fall season.

Museums play a pivotal role in cultural and historical preservation but it can be sometimes be hard to get excited about them.  We've all experienced the trials and tribulations of deciding between the grand new museum expo everyone is talking about or going to the world's grandest doughnut shop while traveling.  Museum Hack adds another element to the museum  experience by engaging those like myself who may otherwise be tempted by the more seemingly entertaining--or sugary-- attractions.

As always, there will be food and drink and much good company.  Kick off the Saturday night Halloween bender early at this months BKTM!

Speaker:

Museum Hack

Museum Hack's mission is to get people excited about great museums all around the world. Guides at Museum Hack give tours that are totally different from most museum experiences: including sassy gossip, games with prizes, and lots of photos. Museum Hack wants to appeal to the cynics, the bored, and the apathetic. They know that a lot of people do not enjoy the current museum experience, especially millennials. Big companies like Google and Adobe regularly hire Museum Hack to produce their company events at the Met. Museums have also been collaborating with Museum Hack for workshops, consulting, and Young Patron program work.

Sponsors 

None of this would be possible without our phenomenal partners, McCarter & English (legal), Cohn Reznick (accounting), Fiverr (service marketplace), and WeWork (co-working). We absolutely recommend them all if you need any help in those areas.
results.name: Building Your Team w/Museum Hack

Meditation leads to inner peace, overcomes loneliness, improves relationships, and has many other benefits for mind and body. We will investigate how meditation works to calm our mind throughout our busy life. Find out how to fit an enjoyable meditation practice into your present lifestyle, and learn time tested methods for improving mindfulness, concentration, and happiness. Beginners and those wanting to continue to learn meditation are welcome in this class.

Concetta Lamore has been a Kadampa meditation practitioner for over 7 years. She exudes gratitude for the wisdom derived from her study of Buddhism and her joyful daily practice. She feels blessed to be able to share the many ways in which our lives can be filled with inner peace and happiness.

venue.name: New York Society for Ethical Culture

results.description:
A Discussion with Matthieu Ricard and Jeffrey Sachs

https://reasonablenewyork.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/jeffreymatthieusmall.jpg?w=300&h=219

How can we balance economic growth, social inclusion, and environmental sustainability? And how can we build social trust and faith in government, to ensure that human and planetary
well-being are at the center of our global politics and policy choices?

Two of the world’s leading thinkers – Matthieu Ricard and Jeffrey Sachs – discuss the questions of ethics, altruism, politics, economics, and sustainable development in this unique event.


Matthieu Ricard is a Buddhist monk, author, translator, and renowned photographer. He is the author of several books including The Monk and the Philosopher; The Quantum and the Lotus; Happiness: A Guide to Developing Life’s Most Important Skill; and Why Meditate?, in addition to five photography books. His new book, Altruism presents a global vision and roadmap for the 21st century, based on decades of personal experience and insight.


Jeffrey D. Sachs is a worldrenowned professor of economics, leader in sustainable development, senior UN advisor, bestselling author, and syndicated columnist whose monthly columns appear in more than 80 countries. Prof. Sachs serves as the Director of The Earth Institute, Quetelet Professor of Sustainable Development, and Professor of Health Policy and Management at Columbia University. He is Special Advisor to United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon. He is Director of the UN Sustainable Development Solutions Network. Prof. Sachs is also co-editor of the World Happiness Report.

Entry to our 100-year-old building and meeting rooms is available for most wheelchair users with prior arrangements. Please call ahead  [masked] x 107) for setup of our portable system and plan to arrive one hour before start time.

This event is proudly brought to you by Soccer Beyond!

Learn more on SoccerBeyond.com or Facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

Details - Fun, interactive, effective.

60min. This is a Coed Soccer Lesson covering soccer techniques for passing, receiving, dribbling, turning, and much more. 

Please bring your own ball. Sneakers, running and turf shoes are fine. Bring some water or sports drink and maybe sun blocker. Please note our Waiver of Liability and 24hr Cancellation Policy below. More details follow.


Rain or Shine - If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Our sessions will be held as scheduled if weather allows. Thunder or snow and ice are among the reasons for sessions to be canceled/ moved. BUT: Don't make assumptions - you will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved. As the weather changes quickly in NYC, occasionally we may make the final decision about 90min prior to session start. If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Cancelled/ Moved Sessions - You will always get notified!

Every time we have to cancel a session, if possible, we move it to the same day and time of the following week. In this case, all players keep their spots. Please email us prior to the rescheduled event, if you can't make and wish a refund or credit. The 24 hours cancellation policy applies. You will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved.

Requesting a Refund

To request a refund 1) change your status to "not going" and 2) send us a note with the Paypal transaction number related to the payment for the respective session. Refunds are processed once a week - please be patient.


24 Hours Cancellation Policy

A full refund/ credit will be given if cancellation is received at least 24 hours prior to lesson start. Full payment is required thereafter. Our cancellation policy also applies to package holders.


Waiver of Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement

By RSVP'ing for this event you certify that you are physically fit such as you are able to participate in this program. You therewith voluntarily release CoachFrankNYC/ Soccer Beyond, LLC from any and all liability resulting from or arising out of your participation and/ or receipt of instruction. You read and agree to the WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT to be found on SoccerBeyond.com/pages/waiver.

Please let us know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Coach Frank

The City of Jersey City and it's Department of Innovation (led by Brian Platt) is in the final stages of developing a new iteration of it's Open Data Portal, and they wanted to have OpenJC/ Code for JC members help them with final revisions in order to ensure this new tool meets the needs of our residents and anyone that might be using this tool.  

Before they start to officially publicize this, they are hoping to have anyone who is interested in taking a look and let them know if this is a step in the right direction, if there are things you like or don’t like, if there are things you would like the CIty to prioritize for additions or changes, or any other comments or questions you might have.  It will also help to have some fresh eyes review and let them know if at the very least this new site makes sense. 

The new site can be found here: http://data.jerseycitynj.gov.

2nd and 4th Tuesday of every month - 7:30pm - 9:30pm

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

No fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP 24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

Name of the school William J. O’Shea (100W): The school entrance is located on West 77th street between Columbus and Amsterdam avenues (pretty much in the middle of the block) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right), Please wait and someone will open the door for you.  the court is on the second floor. 

For questions: Use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!
